title: Provides Batch Functions and Visualisation for Basic Statistical Procedures
text: rfriend R package designed streamline data analysis statistical testing wrapping complex repetitive code convenient, user-friendly functions prefixed f_. primary focus data exploration, statistical tests, creating publication-ready output multiple formats including PDF, Microsoft Word, Excel. package helps write shorter code producing well-formatted summaries, visualizations, statistical tests, automatically handling data transformations, assumption checking, post hoc testing.

title: Provides Batch Functions and Visualisation for Basic Statistical Procedures
text: Summary Tables: f_summary() generates comprehensive summary tables. f_boxcox() Box-Cox transformations (wrapping MASS/boxcox rcompanion) f_bestNormalize() wraps extends normalization bestNormalize package. Boxplots (f_boxplot()) QQ-plots (f_qqnorm()) Histograms (f_hist()) Density plots ANOVA: f_aov() Kruskal-Wallis: f_kruskal_test() Generalized Linear Models: f_glm() Chi-square Tests: f_chisq_test() Model Comparison: Compare models easily f_model_comparison(). f_clear() clears workspace restarts R. f_setwd() sets working directory current script’s location. f_theme() switches RStudio themes quickly. f_factors() converts multiple dataframe columns factors.

title: Provides Batch Functions and Visualisation for Basic Statistical Procedures
text: rfriend requires R (>= 4.4.0) several dependencies (see DESCRIPTION details). can install latest released version CRAN : want latest development version (available GitHub):
code: install.packages("rfriend") # install.packages("devtools")  devtools::install_github("delde001/rfriend")

title: Provides Batch Functions and Visualisation for Basic Statistical Procedures
text: detailed usage examples, please refer package vignettes help files.
code: library(rfriend)  # Summary of your dataset   f_summary(your_dataframe)  # Run ANOVA on multiple response variables   f_aov(response_var1 +  response_var1 ~ predictor1 * predictor2, data = your_dataframe)  # Create a boxplot of a variable   data(mtcars)   f_boxplot(hp + disp ~ gear*cyl,              data=mtcars,              boxplot_explanation = FALSE,              output_type = "word"              )  # Perform Box-Cox transformation   transformed <- f_boxcox(your_dataframe$variable)  # Create a boxplot of a variable   data(mtcars)   f_boxplot(hp + disp ~ gear*cyl,              data=mtcars,              boxplot_explanation = FALSE,              output_type = "word"              )  # Perform Box-Cox transformation transformed <- f_boxcox(your_dataframe$variable)  # Clear workspace and restart R   f_clear()

title: Perform multiple aov() functions with optional data transformation, inspection and Post Hoc test. — f_aov
code: f_aov(   formula,   data = NULL,   norm_plots = TRUE,   ANCOVA = FALSE,   transformation = TRUE,   force_transformation = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   adjust = "sidak",   intro_text = TRUE,   close_generated_files = FALSE,   open_generated_files = TRUE,   output_type = "off",   save_as = NULL,   save_in_wdir = FALSE )

title: Perform multiple aov() functions with optional data transformation, inspection and Post Hoc test. — f_aov
text: formula formula specifying model fitted. response variables can added using - + (e.g., response1 + response2 ~ predictor) sequential aov() response parameter. data data frame containing variables model. norm_plots Logical. TRUE, plots included output files. Default TRUE. ANCOVA Logical. TRUE, prevents automatic conversion predictors factors, allowing Analysis Covariance (ANCOVA). Default FALSE. transformation Logical character string. TRUE, "bestnormalize", applies bestNormalize() transformation residuals normal. "boxcox" applies boxcox transformation. FALSE transformation applied. Default TRUE. force_transformation Character string. vector containing names response variables transformed regardless normality test. Default NULL alpha Numeric. Significance level ANOVA, post hoc tests, Shapiro-Wilk test. Default 0.05. adjust Character string specifying method used adjust p-values multiple comparisons. Available methods include: "tukey" Tukey's Honest Significant Difference method, appropriate                 pairwise comparisons. Controls family-wise error rate. "sidak" Šidák correction controls family-wise error rate.                 Less conservative Bonferroni. "bonferroni" Conservative adjustment multiplies p-values                      number comparisons. "none" adjustment. Equivalent Fisher's LSD method. "fdr" False Discovery Rate adjustment, controls expected proportion               false positives among significant results. Default "sidak". intro_text Logical. TRUE, includes short explanation ANOVA assumptions output file. Default TRUE. close_generated_files Logical. TRUE, closes open 'Excel' 'Word' files depending output format. able save newly generated file f_aov() function. 'Pdf' files also closed using function automatically closed. Default FALSE. open_generated_files Logical. TRUE, Opens generated output files ('pdf', 'Word' 'Excel') files depending output format. directly view results creation. Files stored tempdir(). Default TRUE. output_type Character string specifying output format: "pdf", "word", "excel", "rmd", "console" "" (file generated). option "console" forces output printed, option "rmd" saves rmd code output object file. Default "". save_as Character string specifying output file path (without extension). full path provided, output saved location. filename given, file saved tempdir(). directory specified (providing existing directory trailing slash), file named "dataname_aov_output" directory. extension provided output format specified option "output_type" overruled. Defaults file.path(tempdir(), "dataname_summary.pdf"). save_in_wdir Logical. TRUE, saves file working directory. Default FALSE, avoid unintended changes global environment. save_as location specified save_in_wdir overwritten save_as.

title: Perform multiple aov() functions with optional data transformation, inspection and Post Hoc test. — f_aov
text: object class 'f_aov' containing results aov(), normality tests, transformations, post hoc tests. Using option "output_type", can also generate output form : R Markdown code, 'Word', 'pdf', 'Excel' files. Includes print plot methods 'f_aov' objects.

title: Perform multiple aov() functions with optional data transformation, inspection and Post Hoc test. — f_aov
text: function performs following steps: Check specified variables present data. Ensure response variable numeric. Perform Analysis Variance (ANOVA) using specified formula data. shapiro = TRUE, check normality residuals using Shapiro-Wilk test. residuals normal transformation = TRUE apply data transformation. significant differences found ANOVA, proceed post hoc tests using estimated marginal means emmeans() Sidak adjustment (another option adjust =. response variables can added using - + (e.g., response1 + response2 ~ predictor) sequential aov() response parameter captured one output file. Outputs can generated multiple formats ("pdf", "word", "excel" "rmd") specified output_type. function also closes open 'Word' files avoid conflicts generating 'Word' documents. output_type = "rmd" used adviced use chunk {r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'} function requires [Pandoc](https://github.com/jgm/pandoc/releases/tag) (version 1.12.3 higher), universal document converter. Windows: Install Pandoc ensure installation folder.  (e.g., "C:/Users/your_username/AppData/Local/Pandoc") added system PATH. macOS: using Homebrew, Pandoc typically installed "/usr/local/bin". Alternatively, download .pkg installer verify binary’s location PATH. Linux: Install Pandoc distribution’s package manager (commonly installed "/usr/bin" "/usr/local/bin") manually, ensure directory containing Pandoc PATH. Pandoc found, function may work intended.

title: Perform multiple aov() functions with optional data transformation, inspection and Post Hoc test. — f_aov
code: # Make a factor of Species. iris$Species <- factor(iris$Species)  # The left hand side contains two response variables, # so two aov's will be conducted, i.e. "Sepal.Width" # and "Sepal.Length" in response to the explanatory variable: "Species". f_aov_out <- f_aov(Sepal.Width + Sepal.Length ~ Species,                    data = iris,                    # Save output in MS Word file (Default is console)                    output_type = "word",                    # Do boxcox transformation for non-normal residual (Default is bestnormalize)                    transformation = "boxcox",                    # Do not automatically open the file.                    open_generated_files = FALSE                    ) #> Saving output in: /tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/iris_aov_output.docx  # Print output to the console. print(f_aov_out) #>  #>     #> ========================================================== #>    ANOVA of repsone variable:  Sepal.Width  #> =========================================================== #>  #>  aov call:  Sepal.Width ~ Species  #>  #> Summary Table: #>              Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)     #> Species       2  11.35   5.672   49.16 <2e-16 *** #> Residuals   147  16.96   0.115                    #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Post-Hoc Analysis: #>  Species    emmean        SE  df lower.CL upper.CL Letter #>  versicolor  2.770 0.0480391 147 2.653974 2.886026  a     #>  virginica   2.974 0.0480391 147 2.857974 3.090026   b    #>  setosa      3.428 0.0480391 147 3.311974 3.544026    c   #>  #> Confidence level used: 0.95  #> Conf-level adjustment: sidak method for 3 estimates  #> P value adjustment: sidak method for 3 tests  #> significance level used: alpha = 0.05  #> NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol, #>       then we cannot show them to be different. #>       But we also did not show them to be the same.  #>  #>     #> ========================================================== #>    ANOVA of Box-Cox TRANSFORMED repsone variable: Sepal.Length  #> =========================================================== #>  #>  aov call:  Sepal.Length ~ Species  #>  #> TRANSFORMED Summary Table: #>              Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)     #> Species       2  63.21  31.606   119.3 <2e-16 *** #> Residuals   147  38.96   0.265                    #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> TRANSFORMED Post-Hoc Analysis: #>  Species      emmean          SE  df lower.CL upper.CL Letter #>  setosa     1.434181 0.009363675 147 1.411565 1.456796  a     #>  versicolor 1.566352 0.009363675 147 1.543737 1.588968   b    #>  virginica  1.645523 0.009363675 147 1.622908 1.668139    c   #>  #> Confidence level used: 0.95  #> Conf-level adjustment: sidak method for 3 estimates  #> P value adjustment: sidak method for 3 tests  #> significance level used: alpha = 0.05  #> NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol, #>       then we cannot show them to be different. #>       But we also did not show them to be the same.  #>  #>      # Plot residual plots. plot(f_aov_out)      #To print rmd output set chunck option to results = 'asis' and use cat(). f_aov_rmd_out <- f_aov(Sepal.Width ~ Species, data = iris, output_type = "rmd") cat(f_aov_rmd_out$rmd) #>  #> # Assumptions of ANOVA #> Checking the assumptions of ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) are critical for ensuring the validity of its results: #>  #>  #> ## 1. Independence #> - Observations must be independent both within and between groups. #> - This means that the value of one observation should not influence another. #> - Independence violations cannot be corrected statistically and invalidate the analysis, making proper experimental design essential. #>  #> ## 2. Normality #> - The residuals (errors) of the model are assumed to be normally distributed. #> - This assumption applies to the residuals, not necessarily the raw data. #> - ANOVA is robust to minor deviations from normality, especially with large and balanced sample sizes. For small or unbalanced samples, violations can lead to **unreliable results**, requiring a data transformation or alternative tests (Welch's ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis Test). #> - Normality of the residuals can be tested using a Shapiro Wilcoxon or Anderson-Darling Test. It can also be graphically assessed using a Box Plot, Q-Q plot or Histogram (see figure below). #>  #> ## 3. Homogeneity of Variances (Homoscedasticity) #> - The variances within each group should be approximately equal. #> - Equal  variances ensure that the F-test statistic is reliable. #> - Homogeneity of variances assumption in ANOVA should be tested on the residuals, not directly on the raw data. #> - Levene's test or Bartlett's test can be applied to check for homogeneity of variances. #> - If violated, a data transformation or alternative tests (Welch's ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis Test) are required.  It can also be graphically assessed by plotting residuals vs. fitted values and checking for patterns. #>  #>  #> ## 4. Additivity (No Unaccounted Systematic Effects) #> - For models without interaction terms, it is assumed that the effects of different factors are additive. That is, the combined effect of factors can be expressed as the sum of their individual effects. #> - However, if interaction terms are included in the model, this assumption does not apply because ANOVA explicitly accounts for interactions.   #>    #>     #>    #> # Analysis of:  Sepal.Width    #>    #> ## Normality and homoscedasticity of residuals of:  Sepal.Width    #> Levene's test for homogeneity of residuals: F-Statisic = 0.5902 p-value = 0.5555     #>  According to 'Levene's Test' (0.5555 > 0.05) residuals **have equal variance** (homoscedasticity).   #>    #>     #> Shapiro-Wilk Test for Normality of residuals: W = 0.9895 p-value = 0.323     #>  According to 'Shapiro-Wilk Test' (0.323 > 0.05) residuals **ARE normally distributed**.   #>    #>     #> Anderson-Darling normality test : A = 0.495  p = 0.2116     #> Check the plots in the figure below to assess normality.   #> ![](/tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/file20964b27ed1e.png)     #>    #>   #>     #>  #>     #> ## ANOVA Summary of  Sepal.Width    #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #>            Df    Sum Sq   Mean Sq   F value   Pr(>F)          #> --------------- ----- -------- --------- --------- --------------- #> **Species**     2     11.34    5.6725    49.16     **4.492e-17**   #>  #> **Residuals**   147   16.96    0.1154    NA        NA              #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #>  #>     #>    #> aov call:  Sepal.Width ~ Species  #>    #>      #>    #>    #> ## Post Hoc Test Results of  Sepal.Width    #>  #> -------------------------------------------------------------------- #> Species      emmean   SE        df    lower.CL   upper.CL   Letter   #> ------------ -------- --------- ----- ---------- ---------- -------- #> versicolor   2.770    0.04804   147   2.654      2.886      a        #>  #> virginica    2.974    0.04804   147   2.858      3.090      b        #>  #> setosa       3.428    0.04804   147   3.312      3.544      c        #> -------------------------------------------------------------------- #>  #> Confidence level used: 0.95   #> Conf-level adjustment: sidak method for 3 estimates   #> P value adjustment: sidak method for 3 tests   #> significance level used: alpha = 0.05   #> NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol, #>       then we cannot show them to be different. #>       But we also did not show them to be the same.

text: Sander H. van Delden  plantmind@proton.

title: f_bestNormalize: Automated Data Normalization with bestNormalize — f_bestNormalize
code: # \donttest{ # Create some skewed data (e.g., using a log-normal distribution). skewed_data <- rlnorm(100, meanlog = 0, sdlog = 1)  # Use set.seed to keep the outcome of bestNormalize stable. set.seed(123)  # Transform the data and store all information in f_bestNormalize_out. f_bestNormalize_out <- f_bestNormalize(skewed_data)  # Print the output. print(f_bestNormalize_out) #>  #> Data transformation of skewed_data using `bestNormalize`: Quantile Normalization (ORQ)  #> Original Data Shapiro-Wilk Test:    W = 0.5823   p-value = 2.009e-15  #> Transformed Data Shapiro-Wilk Test: W = 0.9996   p-value = 1  #>    #> Below are all considered transformations: [Pearson P / df, lower => more normal]   (n=100) #>                Transformation Normality_Stat #>                    arcsinh(x)          2.324 #>                       Box-Cox          2.402 #>                  Center+scale         14.180 #>    Double Reversed Log_b(x+a)         47.855 #>                        Exp(x)        115.065 #>                 Log-transform          1.674 #>  Quantile Normalization (ORQ)          0.062 #>                   sqrt(x + a)          3.702 #>                   Yeo-Johnson          1.362 #>     #>  #> Check the normality plots, by using the plot() function or 'plots = TRUE' option  # Show histograms and QQplots. plot(f_bestNormalize_out)   # Directly store the transformed_data from f_bestNormalize and force to show # plots and transformation information. transformed_data <- f_bestNormalize(skewed_data, output_type = "console")$transformed_data #>  #> Data transformation of skewed_data using `bestNormalize`: Quantile Normalization (ORQ)  #> Original Data Shapiro-Wilk Test:    W = 0.5823   p-value = 2.009e-15  #> Transformed Data Shapiro-Wilk Test: W = 0.9996   p-value = 1  #>    #> Below are all considered transformations: [Pearson P / df, lower => more normal]   (n=100) #>                Transformation Normality_Stat #>                    arcsinh(x)          2.324 #>                       Box-Cox          2.402 #>                  Center+scale         14.180 #>    Double Reversed Log_b(x+a)         47.855 #>                        Exp(x)        115.065 #>                 Log-transform          1.674 #>  Quantile Normalization (ORQ)          0.062 #>                   sqrt(x + a)          3.702 #>                   Yeo-Johnson          1.362 #>     #>  #> Check the normality plots, by using the plot() function or 'plots = TRUE' option    # Any other transformation can be choosen by using: boxcox_transformed_data <- f_bestNormalize(skewed_data)$bestNormalize$other_transforms$boxcox$x.t # and substituting '$boxcox' with the transformation of choice.  #To print rmd output set chunck option to results = 'asis' and use: f_bestNormalize_rmd_out <- f_bestNormalize(skewed_data, output_type = "rmd") cat(f_bestNormalize_rmd_out$rmd) #>  #>     #> ##  Data transformation of  skewed_data using `bestNormalize`: Quantile Normalization (ORQ) .   #>    #> **Original Data Shapiro-Wilk Test:**        W = 0.5823    p-value = 2.0093e-15  #>  #> **Transformed Data Shapiro-Wilk Test:** W = 0.9996    p-value = 1  #>    #>      #>    #> **Table.** All considered transformations: [Pearson P / df, lower => more normal]   (n=100) #>  #> ------------------------------------------- #> Transforma                     Normality_   #> tion                           Stat         #> ------------------------------ ------------ #> arcsinh(x)                     2.324        #>  #> Box-Cox                        2.402        #>  #> Center+scale                   14.180       #>  #> Double Reversed Log_b(x+a)     47.855       #>  #> Exp(x)                         115.065      #>  #> Log-transform                  1.674        #>  #> Quantile Normalization (ORQ)   0.062        #>  #> sqrt(x + a)                    3.702        #>  #> Yeo-Johnson                    1.362        #> ------------------------------------------- # }

title: f_boxcox: A User-Friendly Box-Cox Transformation — f_boxcox
text: function uses following formula transformation: $$  y(\lambda) =    \begin{cases}  \frac{y^\lambda - 1}{\lambda}, & \lambda \neq 0 \\  \log(y), & \lambda = 0  \end{cases} $$ (\(y\)) data transformed, (\(\lambda\)) transformation parameter, estimated data using maximum likelihood. function computes Box-Cox transformation range \(\lambda\) values identifies \(\lambda\) maximizes log-likelihood function. beauty transformation , checks suitability many common transformations one run. Examples common transformations \(\lambda\) value given : estimated transformation parameter closely aligns one values listed previous table, generally advisable select table value rather precise estimated value. approach simplifies interpretation practical application. function provides diagnostic plots: plot log-likelihood \(\lambda\) values Q-Q plot transformed data.also performs Shapiro-Wilk test normality transformed data sample size less equal 5000. Note: sample sizes greater 5000, Shapiro-Wilk test results provided due limitations applicability. function requires [Pandoc](https://github.com/jgm/pandoc/releases/tag) (version 1.12.3 higher), universal document converter. Windows: Install Pandoc ensure installation folder  (e.g., "C:/Users/your_username/AppData/Local/Pandoc") added system PATH. macOS: using Homebrew, Pandoc typically installed "/usr/local/bin". Alternatively, download .pkg installer verify binary’s location PATH. title: Generate a Boxplot Report of a data.frame — f_boxplot
code: # \donttest{ # Example usage: data(iris)  new_names = c(   "Sepal.Length" = "Sepal length (cm)" ,   "Sepal.Width" = "Sepal width (cm)",   "Petal.Length" = "Petal length (cm)",   "Petal.Width" = "Petal width (cm)",   "Species" = "Cultivar" )  # Use the whole data.frame to generate an MS Word report and don't open it. f_boxplot(iris,            fancy_names = new_names,            output_type = "word",            open_generated_files = FALSE            ) #> Saving output in: /tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/iris_BoxPlot.docx  # Use a formula to plot several response parameters (response 1 + response 2 etc) # and generate a rmd output without boxplot_explanation. data(mtcars) f_boxplot(hp + disp ~ gear*cyl,            data=mtcars,            boxplot_explanation = FALSE,            output_type = "word",            open_generated_files = FALSE) # Do not automatically open the 'Word' file. #> Saving output in: /tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/mtcars_BoxPlot.docx # }

title: Chi-squared Test with Post-hoc Analysis — f_chisq_test
text: x numeric vector (factor), contingency table matrix table form. data frame entered function try convert table. y numeric vector; ignored x matrix, table data.frame. x factor, y factor length. p vector probabilities length x. Default NULL. error given entry p negative. method Character string specifying adjustment method p-values. Default "bonferroni". options include "holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "BH", "", "fdr", "none". digits Integer specifying number decimal places rounding. Default 3. alpha Numeric threshold significance. Default 0.05. force_posthoc Logical indicating whether perform post-hoc tests even chi-squared test significant. Default FALSE. ... Additional arguments passed chisq.test.

title: Chi-squared Test with Post-hoc Analysis — f_chisq_test
text: object class f_chisq_test containing: chisq_test_output: output chisq.test. adjusted_p_values: Matrix adjusted p-values (table/matrix input). observed_vs_adj_p_value: Interleaved table observed values adjusted p-values. stdres_vs_adj_p_value: Interleaved table standardized residuals adjusted p-values. adj_p_values: Vector adjusted p-values (vector input). posthoc_output_table: Data frame observed values, expected values,         standardized residuals, adjusted p-values (vector input).

title: Chi-squared Test with Post-hoc Analysis — f_chisq_test
text: function first performs chi-squared test using chisq.test. test significant (p < alpha) force_posthoc = TRUE, conducts post-hoc analysis examining standardized residuals. p-values residuals adjusted using specified method control multiple comparisons. input data frame, function attempts convert table displays resulting table verification.

title: Chi-squared Test with Post-hoc Analysis — f_chisq_test
text: function implements post-hoc analysis chi-squared tests inspired methodology : Beasley, T. M., & Schumacker, R. E. (1995). Multiple Regression Approach Analyzing Contingency Tables: Post Hoc Planned Comparison Procedures. Journal Experimental Education, 64(1), 79-93. implementation draws inspiration 'chisq.posthoc.test' package Daniel Ebbert.

title: Chi-squared Test with Post-hoc Analysis — f_chisq_test
text: Sander H. van Delden  plantmind@proton.

title: Chi-squared Test with Post-hoc Analysis — f_chisq_test
code: # Chi.square on independence: Association between two variables. # Create a contingency table. my_table <- as.table(rbind(c(100, 150, 50), c(120, 90, 40))) dimnames(my_table) <- list(Gender = c("Male", "Female"),                            Response = c("Agree", "Neutral", "Disagree"))  # Perform chi-squared test with post-hoc analysis. f_chisq_test(my_table) #> Error in eval(bquote(stats::chisq.test(.(as.name(x_name)), ...)), envir = env): object 'my_table' not found  # Use a different adjustment method. f_chisq_test(my_table, method = "holm") #> Error in eval(bquote(stats::chisq.test(.(as.name(x_name)), ...)), envir = env): object 'my_table' not found  # Other forms still work like Goodness-of-Fit: Match to theoretical distribution. # Observed frequencies of rolling with a die 1 - 6. observed <- c(2, 2, 10, 20, 15, 11)  # Expected probabilities under a fair die. expected_probs <- rep(1/6, 6)  # Chi-Square Goodness-of-Fit Test. f_chisq_test(x = observed, p = expected_probs) #> Error in eval(bquote(stats::chisq.test(.(as.name(x_name)), ...)), envir = env): object 'observed' not found

title: Conditional Rounding for Numeric Values — f_conditional_round
text: x numeric vector data frame containing numeric columns formatted. threshold_small Numeric value. Values absolute magnitude smaller threshold formatted using scientific notation. Default 0.01. threshold_large Numeric value. Values absolute magnitude larger equal threshold formatted using scientific notation. Default 9999. digits Integer. Number significant digits use formatting. Default 3. replace_na Logical. TRUE, NA values replaced empty strings ("") output. Default TRUE. detect_int_col Logical. TRUE, columns data.frame containing integers displayed without decimal digits. Columns containing mix integers decimal values display values specified number digits. FALSE, individual cell evaluated: integer values displayed without digits, numbers containing digits specified number digits. Default TRUE.

title: Conditional Rounding for Numeric Values — f_conditional_round
text: input vector: character vector length input, values formatted according specified rules. input data frame: data frame structure input, character columns formatted according specified rules.

title: Conditional Rounding for Numeric Values — f_conditional_round
text: function applies following formatting rules: Values smaller threshold_small larger threshold_large         formatted scientific notation digits significant digits. Integer values formatted without decimal places. Non-integer values require scientific notation rounded         digits decimal places. NA values replaced empty strings replace_na = TRUE. Empty strings input preserved. data frames, numeric columns processed; columns remain unchanged.

title: Conditional Rounding for Numeric Values — f_conditional_round
text: Sander H. van Delden  plantmind@proton.

title: Conditional Rounding for Numeric Values — f_conditional_round
code: # Vector examples. f_conditional_round(c(0.0001, 0.5, 3, 10000)) #> [1] "1.000e-04" "0.500"     "3.000"     "1.000e+04" # Returns: "1.000e-04" "0.500" "3" "1.000e+04".  f_conditional_round(c(0.0001, 0.5, 3, 10000, NA), replace_na = TRUE) #> [1] "1.000e-04" "0.500"     "3.000"     "1.000e+04" ""          # Returns: "1.000e-04" "0.500" "3" "1.000e+04" ""  # Data frame example. df <- data.frame(   name = c("A", "B", "C"),   small_val = c(0.0001, 0.002, 0.5),   integer = c(1, 2, 3),   integer_mix = c(10, 20, 30.1),   large_val = c(10000, 5000, NA) )  # Show only two digits. f_conditional_round(df, digits = 2) #>   name small_val integer integer_mix large_val #> 1    A  1.00e-04       1       10.00     1e+04 #> 2    B  2.00e-03       2       20.00      5000 #> 3    C      0.50       3       30.10            # To keep Integers as Integers (no digits) # in columns with mixed data (Integers and digits) # set detect_int_col = FALSE f_conditional_round(df, detect_int_col = FALSE) #>   name small_val integer integer_mix large_val #> 1    A 1.000e-04       1          10 1.000e+04 #> 2    B 2.000e-03       2          20      5000 #> 3    C     0.500       3      30.100

text: data data frame containing columns converted. select character vector specifying names columns convert factors. NULL, function automatically detects columns factors based data type unique value count. Default NULL. exclude character vector specifying names columns convert factors. NULL, columns excluded. Default NULL. properties Logical. TRUE, prints detailed table properties new data frame console. FALSE property table printed console. Default FALSE. force_factors Logical. TRUE columns data.frame converted factors except excluded columns using exclude. unique_num_treshold Numeric. threshold amount unique numbers numeric column keep numeric, .e. omit factor conversion. Default 8. repeats_threshold Numeric. threshold minimal number repeats numeric column convert factor. Default 2. ... Additional arguments passed factor() function baseR.

title: Convert multiple columns to Factors in a data frame — f_factors
text: select NULL, function identifies columns character data numeric data fewer 8 unique values candidates conversion factors. function checks specified columns exist data frame stops execution missing. Converts specified columns factors, applying additional arguments provided. Outputs summary data frame details column, including type, class, number observations, missing values, factor levels, labels.

title: Convert multiple columns to Factors in a data frame — f_factors
text: Sander H. van Delden  plantmind@proton.

title: Convert multiple columns to Factors in a data frame — f_factors
code: # Make a data.frame: df <- data.frame(a = c("yes", "no", "yes", "yes", "no",                        "yes", "yes", "no", "yes"),                  b = c(1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3),                  c = c("apple", "kiwi", "banana", "apple", "kiwi",                         "banana", "apple", "kiwi", "banana"),                  d = c(1.1, 1.1, 3.4, 4.5, 5.4, 6.7, 7.8, 8.1, 9.8)                  ) str(df) #> 'data.frame':	9 obs. of  4 variables: #>  $ a: chr  "yes" "no" "yes" "yes" ... #>  $ b: num  1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 #>  $ c: chr  "apple" "kiwi" "banana" "apple" ... #>  $ d: num  1.1 1.1 3.4 4.5 5.4 6.7 7.8 8.1 9.8  # Convert specified columns to factors: df1 <- f_factors(df, select = c("a", "c")) str(df1) #> 'data.frame':	9 obs. of  4 variables: #>  $ a: Factor w/ 2 levels "no","yes": 2 1 2 2 1 2 2 1 2 #>  $ b: num  1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 #>  $ c: Factor w/ 3 levels "apple","banana",..: 1 3 2 1 3 2 1 3 2 #>  $ d: num  1.1 1.1 3.4 4.5 5.4 6.7 7.8 8.1 9.8   # Convert all potential factor columns to factor but exclude column "b": df2 <- f_factors(df, exclude = c("b")) str(df2) #> 'data.frame':	9 obs. of  4 variables: #>  $ a: Factor w/ 2 levels "no","yes": 2 1 2 2 1 2 2 1 2 #>  $ b: num  1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 #>  $ c: Factor w/ 3 levels "apple","banana",..: 1 3 2 1 3 2 1 3 2 #>  $ d: num  1.1 1.1 3.4 4.5 5.4 6.7 7.8 8.1 9.8  # Convert all columns to factor but exclude column "b": df3 <- f_factors(df, exclude = c("b"), force_factors = TRUE) str(df3) #> 'data.frame':	9 obs. of  4 variables: #>  $ a: Factor w/ 2 levels "no","yes": 2 1 2 2 1 2 2 1 2 #>  $ b: num  1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 #>  $ c: Factor w/ 3 levels "apple","banana",..: 1 3 2 1 3 2 1 3 2 #>  $ d: Factor w/ 8 levels "1.1","3.4","4.5",..: 1 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8  # Or automatically detect and convert suitable columns to factors. # Thus obtaining the same results as above automatically: df4 <- f_factors(df) str(df4) #> 'data.frame':	9 obs. of  4 variables: #>  $ a: Factor w/ 2 levels "no","yes": 2 1 2 2 1 2 2 1 2 #>  $ b: Factor w/ 3 levels "1","2","3": 1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 #>  $ c: Factor w/ 3 levels "apple","banana",..: 1 3 2 1 3 2 1 3 2 #>  $ d: num  1.1 1.1 3.4 4.5 5.4 6.7 7.8 8.1 9.8  # In example above col b was converted to a factor as the number of repeats = 2 # and the amount of unique numbers < 8. In order to keep b numeric we can also # adjust the unique_num_treshold and/or repeats_threshold: df5 <- f_factors(df, unique_num_treshold = 2) str(df5) #> 'data.frame':	9 obs. of  4 variables: #>  $ a: Factor w/ 2 levels "no","yes": 2 1 2 2 1 2 2 1 2 #>  $ b: num  1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3 #>  $ c: Factor w/ 3 levels "apple","banana",..: 1 3 2 1 3 2 1 3 2 #>  $ d: num  1.1 1.1 3.4 4.5 5.4 6.7 7.8 8.1 9.8  # Use `properties = TRUE` to view the data frame's structure. # This forces a printed output which is more insight than standard str() output. df6 <- f_factors(df, properties = TRUE) #>   Column    Type   Class Obs Missing Factor_Levels       Factor_Labels #> a      a integer  factor   9       0             2             no, yes #> b      b integer  factor   9       0             3             1, 2, 3 #> c      c integer  factor   9       0             3 apple, banana, kiwi #> d      d  double numeric   9       0             0                     #>

title: Perform multiple glm() functions with diagnostics, assumption checking, and post-hoc analysis — f_glm
text: formula formula specifying model fitted. response variables can added using - + (e.g., response1 + response2 ~ predictor) sequential GLM response parameter. family error distribution link function used model (default: gaussian()). can character string naming family function, family function result call family function. (See family details family functions.) data data frame containing variables model. diagnostic_plots Logical. TRUE, plots included output files. alpha Numeric. Significance level tests. Default 0.05. adjust Character string specifying method used adjust p-values multiple comparisons. Available methods include: "tukey" Tukey's Honest Significant Difference method "sidak" Šidák correction "bonferroni" Bonferroni correction "none" adjustment "fdr" False Discovery Rate adjustment Default "sidak". type specifying scale emmeans posthoc results presented, e.g. "link" show results scale variables linear "response" want back transform data interpret results units original data (e.g., probabilities, counts, untransformed measurements). Default "response". intro_text Logical. Default "". save_as Character string specifying output file path (without extension). full path provided, output saved location. filename given, file saved tempdir(). directory specified (providing existing directory trailing slash), file named "dataname_glm_output" directory. extension provided output format specified option "output_type" overruled. Defaults file.path(tempdir(), "dataname_summary.pdf"). save_in_wdir Logical. TRUE, saves file working directory. close_generated_files Logical. TRUE, closes open 'Excel' 'Word' files depending output format. able save newly generated file f_aov() function. 'Pdf' files also closed using function automatically closed. title: Perform multiple glm() functions with diagnostics, assumption checking, and post-hoc analysis — f_glm
code:
# GLM Binomial example with output to console and MS Word file mtcars_mod <- mtcars mtcars_mod$cyl <- as.factor(mtcars_mod$cyl) glm_bin <- f_glm(vs ~ cyl, family = binomial, data = mtcars_mod, output_type = "word", # Do not automatically open the 'Word' file (Default is to open the file) open_generated_files = FALSE) #> Saving output in: /tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/mtcars_mod_glm_output.docx print(glm_bin) #> ========================================== #> GLM of repsone variable: vs #> ========================================== #> #> Call: #> stats::glm(formula = vs ~ cyl, family = family, data = "mtcars_mod") #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) #> (Intercept) 2.303 1.049 2.195 0.0281 * #> cyl6 -2.015 1.297 -1.553 0.1204 #> cyl8 -21.869 2874.131 -0.008 0.9939 #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #> #> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) #> #> Null deviance: 43.860 on 31 degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance: 16.263 on 29 degrees of freedom #> AIC: 22.263 #> #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 18 #> #> #> Post-hoc Comparisons of: vs #> _________________________________________ #> cyl prob SE df asymp.LCL asymp.UCL .group #> 8 0.000 9.14e-06 Inf 0.000 1.000 a #> 6 0.571 1.87e-01 Inf 0.177 0.892 a #> 4 0.909 8.67e-02 Inf 0.450 0.992 a #> #> Confidence level used: 0.95 #> Conf-level adjustment: sidak method for 3 estimates #> Intervals are back-transformed from the logit scale #> P value adjustment: sidak method for 3 tests #> Tests are performed on the log odds ratio scale #> significance level used: alpha = 0.05 #> NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol, #> then we cannot show them to be different. #> But we also did not show them to be the same. # \donttest{ # GLM Poisson example with output to rmd text data(warpbreaks) glm_pos <- f_glm(breaks ~ wool + tension, data = warpbreaks, family = poisson(link = "log"), intro_text = FALSE, output_type = "rmd") cat(cat(glm_pos$rmd)) #> #> #> #> #> # GLM of: breaks #> #> ## Model Diagnostics of: breaks #> #> ![](/tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/file209627789f07.png) #> #> #>
#> \newpage #> #> ## Model Summary of: breaks #> #> #> ```r #> #> Call: #> stats::glm(formula = breaks ~ wool + tension, family = family, #> data = "warpbreaks") #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) #> (Intercept) 3.69196 0.04541 81.302 < 2e-16 *** #> woolB -0.20599 0.05157 -3.994 6.49e-05 *** #> tensionM -0.32132 0.06027 -5.332 9.73e-08 *** #> tensionH -0.51849 0.06396 -8.107 5.21e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #> #> (Dispersion parameter for poisson family taken to be 1) #> #> Null deviance: 297.37 on 53 degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance: 210.39 on 50 degrees of freedom #> AIC: 493.06 #> #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4 #> #> ``` #> #> #> #> ## Model Post-hoc Analysis of: breaks #> #> #> ```r #> wool tension rate SE df asymp.LCL asymp.UCL .group #> B H 19.4 1.13 Inf 16.7 22.7 a #> B M 23.7 1.28 Inf 20.5 27.3 ab #> A H 23.9 1.33 Inf 20.6 27.7 bc #> A M 29.1 1.50 Inf 25.4 33.3 cd #> B L 32.7 1.58 Inf 28.8 37.1 d #> A L 40.1 1.82 Inf 35.6 45.2 e #> #> Confidence level used: 0.95 #> Conf-level adjustment: sidak method for 6 estimates #> Intervals are back-transformed from the log scale #> P value adjustment: sidak method for 15 tests #> Tests are performed on the log scale #> significance level used: alpha = 0.05 #> NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol, #> then we cannot show them to be different. #> But we also did not show them to be the same. #> ``` # }

title: Perform multiple Kruskal-Wallis tests with a user-friendly output file, do data inspection and Dunn's test (of 'rstatix') as post hoc. — f_kruskal_test
code: # Example usage: data(iris)  # Perform Kruskal-Wallis test on Sepal.Length and Sepal.Width by Species # with "holm" correction for posthoc dunn_test, without showing the output. output <- f_kruskal_test(                Sepal.Width + Sepal.Length ~ Species,                data = iris,                plot = FALSE,                output_type = "word",                adjust = "holm",                open_generated_files = FALSE                ) #> Saving output in: /tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/iris_Kruskal_Wallis_output.docx  # Save Kruskal-Wallis test and posthoc to Excel sheets: Sepal.Width and Sepal.Length. f_kruskal_out <- f_kruskal_test(                      Sepal.Width + Sepal.Length ~ Species,                      data = iris,                      plot = FALSE,                      output_type = "excel",                      adjust = "holm",                      open_generated_files = FALSE                      ) #> Saving output in: /tmp/RtmpDUIw9V/iris_Kruskal_Wallis_output.xlsx

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
code: f_model_comparison(model1, model2, nested = NULL, digits = 3)

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
text: model1 first model object. Supported classes include: "lm", "glm", "aov", "lmerMod", "glmerMod", "nls". model2 second model object. Supported classes include: "lm", "glm", "aov", "lmerMod", "glmerMod", "nls". nested Logical. TRUE, assumes models nested performs ANOVA comparison. NULL (default), function attempts automatically determine models nested. digits Integer. number decimal places round output metrics. Defaults 3.

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
text: list class "f_model_comparison" containing: model1_name name first model. model2_name name second model. model1_class class first model. model2_class class second model. metrics_table data frame summarizing metrics models, differences, (applicable) ANOVA p-value. formatted_metrics_table formatted version metrics table printing. anova_comparison ANOVA comparison results models nested ANOVA test performed. nested Logical indicating whether models treated nested.

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
text: Calculate various metrics assess model fit: AIC/BIC: Lower values indicate better fit. Log-Likelihood: Higher values (less negative) indicate better fit. R-squared: Proportion variance explained model. Adjusted R-squared: R-squared penalized number parameters (linear models). Nagelkerke R^2: pseudo-R^2 generalized linear models (GLMs). Marginal/Conditional R^2: mixed models, marginal R^2 reflects fixed effects, conditional R^2 includes random effects. Sigma: Residual standard error. Deviance: Model deviance. SSE: Sum squared errors. Parameters (df): Number model parameters. Residual df: Residual degrees freedom. models nested, ANOVA test performed compare , p-value provided assess whether complex model significantly improves fit.

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
text: function supports variety model types may issue warnings unsupported partially supported classes used. GLMs, Nagelkerke's R^2 used pseudo-R^2 approximation. mixed models, function relies 'r.squaredGLMM' function 'MuMIn' package R^2 calculation. idea function (code), got Dustin Fife's function 'model.comparison' super cool 'flexplot package'.

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
text: function supports following model classes: Linear models ("lm") Generalized linear models ("glm") Analysis variance models ("aov") Linear mixed models ("lmerMod") Generalized linear mixed models ("glmerMod") Nonlinear least squares models ("nls")

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
text: Sander H. van Delden  plantmind@proton.

title: Compare Two Statistical Models — f_model_comparison
code: # Example with linear models. model1 <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars) model2 <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars) comparison <- f_model_comparison(model1, model2) print(comparison) #> Comparison of two nested models: #> Model1: model1 (lm)  #> Model2: model2 (lm) #>  #>           Metric  Model1  Model2 Difference #>              AIC 166.029 156.652     -9.377 #>              BIC 170.427 162.515     -7.911 #>   Log-Likelihood -80.015 -74.326      5.689 #>        R-squared   0.753   0.827      0.074 #>   Adj. R-squared   0.745   0.815      0.070 #>            Sigma   3.046   2.593     -0.452 #>         Deviance 278.322 195.048    -83.274 #>              SSE 278.322 195.048    -83.274 #>  Parameters (df)       2       3          1 #>      Residual df      30      29         -1 #>    ANOVA p-value                  1.451e-03 #>  #> Interpretation Guide: #> - Lower AIC/BIC values indicate better model fit. #> - Higher R-squared values indicate better model fit. #> - Adj. R-squared is R-squared with a penalty for #>   the number of model parameters used. #> - A lower Sigma (residual standard error) generally #>   indicates a better fit to the data. #> - For nested models, ANOVA p-value < 0.05 suggests #>   that the more complex model is significantly better.  # Example with GLMs. # \donttest{ model1 <- glm(am ~ wt, data = mtcars, family = binomial) model2 <- glm(am ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars, family = binomial) comparison <- f_model_comparison(model1, model2) print(comparison) #> Comparison of two nested models: #> Model1: model1 (glm)  #> Model2: model2 (glm) #>  #>           Metric Model1 Model2 Difference #>              AIC 23.176 16.059     -7.117 #>              BIC 26.108 20.456     -5.651 #>   Log-Likelihood -9.588 -5.030      4.558 #>   Nagelkerke R^2  0.713  0.871      0.158 #>                                           #>            Sigma      1      1          0 #>         Deviance 19.176 10.059     -9.117 #>              SSE                          #>  Parameters (df)      2      3          1 #>      Residual df     30     29         -1 #>    ANOVA p-value                2.532e-03 #>  #> Interpretation Guide: #> - Lower AIC/BIC values indicate better model fit. #> - Higher R-squared values indicate better model fit. #> - Nagelkerke's R^2 adapts Cox & Snell's R^2 for GLMs, #>   scaling it to a 0-1 range to serve as a pseudo-R^2 #>   approximating explained variance. #> - A lower Sigma (residual standard error) generally #>   indicates a better fit to the data. #> - For nested models, ANOVA p-value < 0.05 suggests #>   that the more complex model is significantly better. # }  # Example with automatic detection of nested models. model1 <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars) model2 <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars) comparison <- f_model_comparison(model1, model2) print(comparison) #> Comparison of two nested models: #> Model1: model1 (lm)  #> Model2: model2 (lm) #>  #>           Metric  Model1  Model2 Difference #>              AIC 166.029 156.652     -9.377 #>              BIC 170.427 162.515     -7.911 #>   Log-Likelihood -80.015 -74.326      5.689 #>        R-squared   0.753   0.827      0.074 #>   Adj. R-squared   0.745   0.815      0.070 #>            Sigma   3.046   2.593     -0.452 #>         Deviance 278.322 195.048    -83.274 #>              SSE 278.322 195.048    -83.274 #>  Parameters (df)       2       3          1 #>      Residual df      30      29         -1 #>    ANOVA p-value                  1.451e-03 #>  #> Interpretation Guide: #> - Lower AIC/BIC values indicate better model fit. #> - Higher R-squared values indicate better model fit. #> - Adj. R-squared is R-squared with a penalty for #>   the number of model parameters used. #> - A lower Sigma (residual standard error) generally #>   indicates a better fit to the data. #> - For nested models, ANOVA p-value < 0.05 suggests #>   that the more complex model is significantly better.

code: # NOTE: The use of "if(interactive())" prevents this example from running # during automated CRAN checks. This is necessary because the example # requires to be run from an R script. You don't need to use # "if(interactive())" in your own scripts. if(interactive()) { # Store the current working directory, so we can reset it after the example. current_wd <-  getwd() print(current_wd)  # Run this commando from a saved R script file, or R Notebook to set the working # directory to scripts' file location f_setwd()  # Restore your current working directory f_setwd(current_wd) }

title: rfriend 2.0.0 (2025-11-16)
text: BREAKING CHANGE: Replaced output_file output_dir arguments single save_as argument file-saving functions. save_as argument now controls full save path (directory, filename extension). accepts relative paths (e.g., "example/filename.pdf") full paths (e.g., "c:/users/tom/docs/filename.pdf"). file extension (like .pdf .word) provided, save_as override output_type argument using extension. Changed default argument output_type = "" output_type = "console" f_aov(), f_kruskal_test(), f_glm(), f_chisq_test(). ensures results printed console default, aligning user expectations. arguments show_assumptions_text f_glm(), kruskal_assumptions_text f_kruskal_test(), aov_assumptions_text f_aov() boxplot_explanation f_boxplot replace argument intro_text short uniform argument.
